sections.title: Composite bonding for measured smile refinement
sections.body: Composite bonding (also called cosmetic bonding or dental bonding) uses layered resin to rebuild edges and balance shapes with minimal drilling. We preserve enamel wherever possible, plan conservatively, and explain how wear and staining can be managed over time.
bullets: Tooth-preserving contouring with light surface preparation
Resins layered to match shade, translucency, and texture
Calm appointment pacing with time for review before final polishing

sections.label: Introduction
sections.title: Conservative improvements, well planned
sections.body:
Composite bonding is a conservative cosmetic treatment used to improve the appearance of teeth by carefully adding tooth-coloured resin to the surface.

It is commonly used to adjust shape, close small gaps, or repair minor chips. Because it involves minimal or no removal of natural tooth structure, it is often considered a lower-intervention option compared with other cosmetic treatments.

Whether composite bonding is appropriate depends on your teeth, bite, and expectations, which we assess before recommending treatment.

sections.title: What composite bonding can and can’t do
items: Adds volume to close small gaps, soften edges, and refine proportions without drilling healthy enamel
Repairs chipped or worn incisal edges; larger fractures or weakened teeth may need onlays or crowns
Helps smooth minor rotations and asymmetry, but major crowding still needs aligners or orthodontics
Can mask shade variations to a degree, yet deep discolouration often responds better to whitening or veneers
Composite will pick up surface stain and light wear; expect periodic polishing to keep results fresh

sections.label: Digital planning
sections.title: Digitally planned and guided bonding
sections.body: We start with 3D scans and photographs, design the proposed changes digitally, and share mock-ups so you can preview the direction. Guided placement and finishing maps keep the resin precise and consistent, and set up injection moulding when it is the safest choice.
sections.mediaHint: Digital smile planning and mock-up visuals

sections.title: Injection moulding technique
sections.body: Injection moulded composite uses digital design and silicone or printed keys to deliver resin through a precise guide. It keeps edge lengths, embrasures, and widths consistent, improves symmetry across multiple teeth, and reduces chairside guesswork.
bullets: Digital scans and wax-ups map planned tooth shapes before treatment
Silicone keys or printed guides control resin volume for repeatable placement
Predictable edge lengths and contact points with fewer mid-appointment adjustments
Efficient when treating several teeth together or refining symmetry after orthodontics

sections.title: How composite bonding fits with other options
items: When colour is the main concern, dentist-led whitening is usually recommended before bonding so shades align
If teeth are rotated or crowded, aligners or other orthodontic treatment can set the foundation before cosmetic bonding
For larger shape changes or durability, porcelain veneers or digitally designed 3D veneers may be more appropriate
Composite bonding often forms part of an Align → Bleach → Composite pathway, with veneers reserved for specific needs

sections.title: Longevity & maintenance
items: Composite bonding is not permanent. Over time, the material can wear, stain, or chip, particularly at the edges.
Longevity varies between individuals and depends on factors such as bite forces, habits, and oral hygiene. Maintenance or repair may be required in the future.
We discuss realistic expectations and ongoing care before treatment begins.

sections.title: When bonding isn’t the best choice
items: Heavy bites or active clenching with limited space may need occlusal therapy or guards first
Severe wear or bite collapse often requires orthodontics, onlays, or veneers for stability
Deep discolouration or large colour jumps are better addressed with whitening or porcelain coverage
Insufficient enamel or untreated gum disease must be managed before cosmetic bonding is planned

faqs.question: How long does composite bonding last?
faqs.answer: With regular hygiene visits, polishing, and a night guard if you clench, many cases stay stable for several years before refreshes are needed.

faqs.question: Can composite bonding be repaired?
faqs.answer: Yes. Chips or edge wear can usually be smoothed and re-layered without removing the rest of the bonding, keeping treatment conservative.

faqs.question: How do I maintain bonded teeth?
faqs.answer: Use non-abrasive toothpaste, attend hygienist visits for polishing, minimise staining foods and smoking, and wear a night guard if advised.

faqs.question: Is composite bonding suitable for everyone?
faqs.answer: Suitability depends on bite forces, enamel quality, and goals. We may recommend whitening, aligners, or veneers instead if the bite is heavy or colour change needed is significant.

sections.title: Who composite bonding suits best
items: Patients wanting cosmetic improvement without irreversible drilling
Those planning staged care such as whitening or orthodontic alignment before final bonding
People exploring a cost-effective step before considering porcelain veneers
Patients who value reversible changes and measured maintenance
